abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Agricultural Pollution
            Control Project for Moldova were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            sustainability and replicability of communal waste
            management depends on local authorities' commitment.
            Train a project implementation unit (PIU) member in
            procurement procedures to aid understanding of fiduciary
            unit requests and improve cooperation. If a PIU under a
            sectoral ministry is in charge of technical aspects, and a
            fiduciary unit under another ministry is in charge of
            procurement and financial management,
            miscommunication/confusion about responsibilities will delay
            implementation. Timely fund allocation, irrespective of
            financing source, maintains implementation pace, and project
            credibility among grant recipients and contractors. Plan for
            mitigating possible resource use conflicts and access
            restrictions when restoring wetlands as a small component in
            a large nutrient reduction project. Be prepared to allocate
            more time to social issues than the share of the activity in
            the overall project costs.

5087646.trustfund:
TF053023-GEF3 FSP-MOLDOVA:AGRICULTURAL
            POLLUTION CONTROL PROJECT,TF050093-GEF2 PDF B -
            MOLDOVA:PREPARATION OF AGRICULTURAL POLLUTION CONTROL PROJ
5087646.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Rural development

abstracts.cdata!:
The Agricultural Pollution Control
            Project aims to  increase significantly the use o f
            environmentally friendly agricultural practices by farmers
            and agro-industry in Moldova in order to reduce nutrient
            discharge from agricultural sources to the Danube River and
            Black Sea. The project has four components. The first
            component has two subcomponents. It promotes mitigation
            measures for reducing nutrient loads in water bodies. This
            component provides grants to entrepreneurs and enterprises
            under the Rural Investment and Services Project (RISP) for
            investing in environmentally sustainable agricultural
            practices; and trains rural advisory service providers in
            several nutrient reduction practices, including crop
            nutrient management, conservation tillage practices, crop
            rotation and tree planting o f buffer strips etc. The first
            component also promotes improving watershed management
            practices, particularly manure management practices,
            environmentally-friendly agricultural practices, shrub and
            tree planting, wetland restoration and sustainable
            management practices, and the monitoring of soil, water
            quality, and environmental impacts. The second component
            strengthens national policy, regulatory enforcement and
            national capacity. The third component supports public
            information campaigns and a replication strategy. The fourth
            component finances project management and evaluation.

repnme.cdata!:
Moldova - Agricultural Pollution Control
            Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental assessment for
            the Moldova Agricultural Pollution Control Project, which
            provides a mix of investment and policy-related activities
            to mainstream environmental practices into the agricultural
            sector. This report describes anticipated negative
            environmental impacts and their mitigations. They are as
            follows: Develop and implement improved manure management
            and environmentally sound agricultural management practices.
            Undertake a rigorous surface water quality monitoring
            program. Reduce nutrient leaching to groundwater quality by
            introducing better manure storage and handling, and nutrient
            management practices. Improve drinking water quality by
            reducing nitrate and bacteria in groundwater through
            collecting manure from individual farmer's homesteads
            and storing in communal platforms. Monitor groundwater
            quality to determine the effect of better nutrient
            management practices. Monitor soil to establish the effect
            of better farming systems on soil erosion and soil and water
            quality. Monitor the increase of flora and fauna resulting
            from the decrease of chemical and fecal material. Observe
            impact on new animal populations and soil worm and microbial
            activity. Measure effects on soil organic matter and carbon
            contents, and possibly water quality.
